steps: Move the person to a warmer location.
Protect the affected area from further exposure. If possible, loosely cover with a clean cloth.
Remove any wet or restrictive clothing.
If there is a chance the affected area may refreeze, it is generally advised to delay rewarming until a safe location is reached.
If rewarming is possible without risk of refreezing, use warm water (not hot, ideally between 104-108°F or 40-42°C). Avoid direct heat sources like a fire or radiator.
Soak the affected area in warm water for 20-30 minutes. If warm water isn't available, use body heat. Do not rub or massage the area.
After rewarming, gently dry the area and wrap it loosely in sterile bandages. Keep the area elevated to help reduce swelling.
If fingers or toes are affected, place cotton balls or gauze between them to keep them separated.
red_flags: Blisters develop on the affected skin.
The skin turns black or hard.
Signs of infection develop (increased pain, swelling, redness, pus).
guidelines.disclaimer: This information is for general first-aid guidance only and is not a substitute for professional medical care. If possible, seek help from a qualified medical professional or emergency services.

steps: Move the person to a cooler environment, ideally an air-conditioned room or a shady spot.
Remove excess clothing to help the body cool down.
Cool the person quickly using any available methods:
- Apply cool water to the skin with a sponge or spray bottle.
- Fan the person to promote evaporation.
- Place ice packs or cool, wet cloths on the neck, armpits, and groin.
Monitor the person's temperature. Continue cooling efforts until the body temperature drops below 102°F (39°C).
If the person is alert and able to swallow, offer cool fluids (water or sports drinks) to rehydrate.
Position the person on their side if they are vomiting to prevent choking.
Monitor the person's breathing and be prepared to administer CPR if necessary.
red_flags: Altered mental state or behavior, such as confusion, disorientation, seizures, or loss of consciousness
Hot, dry skin or profuse sweating
If the person's condition worsens despite cooling efforts.
guidelines.disclaimer: This information is for general first-aid guidance only and is not a substitute for professional medical care. If possible, seek help from a qualified medical professional or emergency services.

steps: If the person is conscious, give them small sips of water or a sports drink.
Move the person to a cooler place, out of direct sunlight.
Help the person lie down and rest.
Loosen any tight or heavy clothing.
If the person is able to drink, continue to give them fluids gradually.
red_flags: Very dark urine or no urine output
guidelines.disclaimer: This information is for general first-aid guidance only and is not a substitute for professional medical care. If possible, seek help from a qualified medical professional or emergency services.

steps: Descend to a lower altitude as quickly and safely as possible. Even a small descent of 1,500 to 3,000 feet can help.
Stop ascending. Do not go any higher until symptoms improve.
Rest. Avoid strenuous activity.
Stay hydrated by drinking plenty of fluids, such as water or sports drinks.
If you have a headache, you can take over-the-counter pain relievers like ibuprofen or acetaminophen.
If nausea is present, consider anti-nausea medication if available and appropriate.
red_flags: Severe headache that doesn't respond to medication.
Shortness of breath, even at rest.
Coughing, especially if producing frothy or pink sputum (possible sign of HAPE - High Altitude Pulmonary Edema).
Confusion, disorientation, or changes in mental status (possible sign of HACE - High Altitude Cerebral Edema).
Difficulty walking or loss of coordination.
guidelines.disclaimer: This information is for general first-aid guidance only and is not a substitute for professional medical care. If possible, seek help from a qualified medical professional or emergency services.

steps: Move the person out of the sun immediately.
Cool the skin with cool (not cold) water. This can be done with a shower, bath, or cool compresses.
Apply a moisturizing lotion to the affected skin.
Drink plenty of fluids to prevent dehydration.
If blisters form, do not break them. Allow them to heal on their own to prevent infection.
Over-the-counter pain relievers (like ibuprofen or acetaminophen) can be taken to reduce pain and inflammation, following package instructions.
Wear loose-fitting clothing to avoid irritating the burnt skin.
red_flags: Signs of dehydration (decreased urination, excessive thirst)
Signs of infection (pus, increased pain, swelling, redness)
guidelines.disclaimer: This information is for general first-aid guidance only and is not a substitute for professional medical care. If possible, seek help from a qualified medical professional or emergency services.

steps: Ensure the scene is safe before approaching the person. Lightning can strike again.
Check the person for responsiveness, breathing, and circulation. If the person is unresponsive and not breathing, begin CPR immediately.
Call for emergency medical help or ask someone else to do so.
Treat any burns. Cool the burn with cool (not ice-cold) water for an extended period. Cover the burn with a sterile bandage or clean cloth.
Look for other injuries, such as fractures or dislocations, and stabilize them as best as possible.
Keep the person warm and as comfortable as possible while waiting for emergency medical services to arrive.
guidelines.disclaimer: This information is for general first-aid guidance only and is not a substitute for professional medical care. If possible, seek help from a qualified medical professional or emergency services.

steps: If the stinger is visible, gently try to remove it. Some sources advise scraping it away with a fingernail or a credit card edge. Avoid squeezing the stinger, which may release more venom.
Wash the area with soap and water.
Apply a cold compress to the sting site to help reduce swelling and pain.
Consider an over-the-counter antihistamine or pain reliever to help alleviate itching, swelling, and discomfort. Follow the product's instructions.
red_flags: Swelling of the face, lips, or tongue
Hives or rash all over the body
guidelines.disclaimer: This information is for general first-aid guidance only and is not a substitute for professional medical care. If possible, seek help from a qualified medical professional or emergency services.

steps: Move away from the snake to prevent further bites.
Call for emergency medical assistance or transport the person to a hospital as quickly as possible.
Keep the person calm and still to slow the spread of venom.
Immobilize the bitten limb and keep it below heart level.
Remove any rings, watches, or tight clothing from the bitten limb.
If possible, note the time of the bite and the snake's appearance (without risking further bites) to help with identification for antivenom treatment.
red_flags: Signs of allergic reaction (hives, itching, swelling of the face, tongue, or throat)
guidelines.disclaimer: This information is for general first-aid guidance only and is not a substitute for professional medical care. If possible, seek help from a qualified medical professional or emergency services.

steps: Wash the bite area gently with soap and water.
Apply a cold compress or ice pack wrapped in cloth to the bite for 10 minutes on, 10 minutes off to help reduce swelling and pain.
Elevate the affected area if possible.
Monitor for signs of infection or a severe reaction.
red_flags: Blistering or ulceration at the bite site
guidelines.disclaimer: This information is for general first-aid guidance only and is not a substitute for professional medical care. If possible, seek help from a qualified medical professional or emergency services.

steps: Use fine-tipped tweezers to grasp the tick as close to the skin's surface as possible.

Pull the tick upward with steady, even pressure. Do not twist or jerk the tick; this can cause the mouthparts to break off and remain in the skin. If this happens, try to remove the mouthparts with clean tweezers. If you can't remove them easily, leave them alone and let the skin heal.
After removing the tick, thoroughly clean the bite area and your hands with rubbing alcohol, an iodine scrub, or soap and water.
Dispose of a live tick by putting it in alcohol, placing it in a sealed bag or container, wrapping it tightly in tape, or flushing it down the toilet. Never crush a tick with your fingers.
Monitor the bite area for any signs of infection or rash.
red_flags: A spreading rash, especially one that looks like a bull's-eye
guidelines.disclaimer: This information is for general first-aid guidance only and is not a substitute for professional medical care. If possible, seek help from a qualified medical professional or emergency services.

steps: Carefully remove any visible tentacles from the skin using tweezers or a gloved hand. Avoid rubbing the area, as this may release more venom.
Rinse the affected area with vinegar for at least 30 seconds. If vinegar is not available, use seawater. Do not use fresh water, as it can worsen the sting.
Apply a cold pack or ice pack wrapped in a cloth to the affected area for 15-20 minutes to help reduce pain and swelling.
If pain persists, over-the-counter pain relievers such as ibuprofen or acetaminophen may be taken according to package instructions.
If itching occurs, an over-the-counter antihistamine may provide relief. Follow package instructions.
Monitor for signs of an allergic reaction or worsening symptoms.
red_flags: Difficulty breathing or shortness of breath
Swelling of the face, lips, or tongue
Signs of infection at the sting site (increased pain, redness, swelling, pus)
guidelines.disclaimer: This information is for general first-aid guidance only and is not a substitute for professional medical care. If possible, seek help from a qualified medical professional or emergency services.

steps: 1. Ensure your safety and the safety of others by securing the dog if possible.
2. Wash the wound thoroughly with soap and water for several minutes.
3. Control any bleeding by applying direct pressure to the wound with a clean cloth.
4. Apply an antiseptic to the wound after cleaning.
5. Cover the wound with a sterile bandage.
6. Seek medical attention, especially if the bite is deep, puncture wound, or if you are unsure of the dog's vaccination history.
red_flags: Signs of infection (increased pain, redness, swelling, pus)
Bite from an unknown or unvaccinated animal
If you have not had a tetanus shot in the last 5 years
If the bite is on the face, hand, or near a joint
guidelines.disclaimer: This information is for general first-aid guidance only and is not a substitute for professional medical care. If possible, seek help from a qualified medical professional or emergency services.

steps: Wash the bite thoroughly with soap and water.
Apply pressure with a clean cloth to stop any bleeding.
Apply an antiseptic ointment to the wound.
Cover the bite with a sterile bandage.
Change the bandage daily and keep the wound clean and dry.
red_flags: Signs of infection (increased pain, redness, swelling, pus)
Red streaks extending from the wound
Bite is deep or involves a joint
Bite on the face, hand, or foot
You are unsure of the biter's vaccination status (tetanus)
guidelines.disclaimer: This information is for general first-aid guidance only and is not a substitute for professional medical care. If possible, seek help from a qualified medical professional or emergency services.

steps: Wash the bite area gently with soap and water.
Apply a cold compress or ice pack to reduce swelling and itching. Apply for 10-20 minutes at a time.
Avoid scratching the bites to prevent infection.
If itching is severe, consider using over-the-counter anti-itch cream or antihistamine.
red_flags: Signs of infection at the bite site (increased pain, swelling, redness, pus)
guidelines.disclaimer: This information is for general first-aid guidance only and is not a substitute for professional medical care. If possible, seek help from a qualified medical professional or emergency services.

steps: 1. Keep the person still and calm.
2. Examine the injured area for open wounds. If present, control bleeding by applying direct pressure with a clean cloth.
3. Immobilize the injured area using a splint and padding. If you don't have a splint, you can use a rolled-up newspaper or magazine.
4. Apply ice packs to the injured area to reduce swelling. Do not apply ice directly to the skin; wrap it in a cloth.
5. Elevate the injured limb if possible.
6. Monitor the person for signs of shock (e.g., pale skin, rapid heartbeat, confusion).
red_flags: The injured person is unresponsive or losing consciousness.
There is an open fracture (bone protruding through the skin).
The injured limb is deformed or at an unnatural angle.
The person has lost feeling or cannot move the injured limb.
There is significant bleeding that cannot be controlled.
guidelines.disclaimer: This information is for general first-aid guidance only and is not a substitute for professional medical care. If possible, seek help from a qualified medical professional or emergency services.

steps: Immobilize the injured joint. Use a splint or sling to prevent movement.
Apply ice packs to the injured area to reduce pain and swelling.
Provide support. Use padding to make the person comfortable.
Seek professional medical attention for realignment of the joint.
guidelines.disclaimer: This information is for general first-aid guidance only and is not a substitute for professional medical care. If possible, seek help from a qualified medical professional or emergency services.

steps: Follow the RICE protocol: Rest, Ice, Compression, and Elevation.
Rest: Avoid putting weight on the injured ankle. Use crutches if necessary.
Ice: Apply an ice pack to the injured area for 15-20 minutes every 2-3 hours. Protect the skin by wrapping the ice pack in a cloth.
Compression: Wrap the ankle with an elastic bandage, but not too tightly. Make sure it's snug but doesn't cut off circulation.
Elevation: Elevate the ankle above heart level to reduce swelling.
Over-the-counter pain relievers, like ibuprofen or acetaminophen, may help manage pain.
red_flags: Severe pain that doesn't improve with pain relievers.
Inability to bear weight on the injured ankle.
Numbness or tingling in the foot or toes.
guidelines.disclaimer: This information is for general first-aid guidance only and is not a substitute for professional medical care. If possible, seek help from a qualified medical professional or emergency services.

steps: Ensure the scene is safe.
Check the person's responsiveness and breathing. If they are unresponsive and not breathing, begin CPR if you are trained.
If the person is breathing, try to keep them still and lying flat.
Apply direct pressure to any bleeding wounds with a clean cloth.
Monitor the person's level of consciousness, breathing, and any other symptoms.
If the person is conscious, ask them questions to assess their memory and orientation (e.g., What is your name? Where are you? What day is it?).
If vomiting occurs, turn the person onto their side to prevent choking, while keeping the head and neck aligned as much as possible.
Keep the person warm and comfortable while waiting for medical help to arrive.
red_flags: Clear fluid or blood draining from the ears or nose
Weakness or numbness in any part of the body
guidelines.disclaimer: This information is for general first-aid guidance only and is not a substitute for professional medical care. If possible, seek help from a qualified medical professional or emergency services.

steps: Assess the situation and ensure the person is in a safe environment.
If the person is unresponsive, check for breathing and pulse. Begin CPR if necessary and you are trained to do so.
If the person is responsive, keep them still and calm. Minimize movement of the head and neck.
Monitor the person for any changes in their condition.
If the person is alert and has no neck pain, they can sit up slowly.
Apply a cold compress to the head or neck if there is swelling or pain.
Do not administer any medication unless directed by a medical professional.
Watch for any worsening symptoms or red flags.
red_flags: Confusion or disorientation that gets worse
Bleeding or clear fluid from the ears or nose
guidelines.disclaimer: This information is for general first-aid guidance only and is not a substitute for professional medical care. If possible, seek help from a qualified medical professional or emergency services.

steps: Handle the tooth carefully. Avoid touching the root.
Rinse the tooth gently with clean water if it's dirty. Do not scrub it.
If possible, try to reinsert the tooth into its socket. Gently push it in using your fingers or by biting down on a soft cloth. Make sure the tooth is facing the right way.
If you can't reinsert the tooth, store it in milk, saliva, or a commercially available tooth preservation solution.
Get to a dentist or emergency room as quickly as possible. Time is critical for saving the tooth.
red_flags: Other injuries to the face or mouth.
If the tooth cannot be reinserted.
If the person is feeling unwell or has other symptoms.
guidelines.disclaimer: This information is for general first-aid guidance only and is not a substitute for professional medical care. If possible, seek help from a qualified medical professional or emergency services.

steps: For minor irritations from small particles: Gently flush the eye with clean, cool water. Use an eyewash cup or pour water from a clean container.

If a chemical is splashed in the eye: Immediately flush the eye with large amounts of clean water for at least 20 minutes. Tilt the head so the water runs away from the other eye. Seek immediate medical attention.
Do not rub the eye. Rubbing can cause further damage.

If a foreign object is embedded in the eye: Do not attempt to remove it. Stabilize the object as best as possible without applying pressure. Cover the eye with a clean cup or shield and seek immediate medical attention.
For cuts or punctures to the eye or eyelid: Gently cover the eye with a sterile dressing or clean cloth. Do not apply pressure. Seek immediate medical attention.
In general, protect the injured eye from further harm. Consider using eye protection if available.
If possible, seek help from a qualified medical professional or emergency services.
red_flags: Vision changes or loss of vision
Foreign object embedded in the eye
guidelines.disclaimer: This information is for general first-aid guidance only and is not a substitute for professional medical care. If possible, seek help from a qualified medical professional or emergency services.

steps: Wash your hands thoroughly with soap and water to help prevent infection.
If the bleeding is minor, allow it to bleed freely for a short time to help flush out any contaminants.
Wash the wound gently with mild soap and water. Avoid scrubbing.
Rinse the wound thoroughly under running water.
If the bleeding continues, apply firm, direct pressure to the wound with a clean cloth. Maintain pressure until the bleeding stops.
Once the bleeding has stopped, apply a thin layer of antibiotic ointment to the wound.
Cover the wound with a sterile bandage to protect it.
Change the bandage daily, or more often if it becomes wet or dirty.
Monitor for signs of infection (redness, swelling, pus, increased pain, fever).
If the puncture wound is deep, or if the object was dirty or rusty, consult a medical professional about a tetanus shot.
red_flags: Signs of infection (redness, swelling, pus, increased pain, fever)
Puncture wound to the chest, abdomen, or head
If you are unsure about your tetanus status
guidelines.disclaimer: This information is for general first-aid guidance only and is not a substitute for professional medical care. If possible, seek help from a qualified medical professional or emergency services.

steps: Recognize the signs of a heart attack, which may include chest pain or discomfort (pressure, squeezing, fullness), pain radiating to the arm, neck, jaw, or back, shortness of breath, nausea, sweating, lightheadedness, or anxiety.
Immediately call emergency services (e.g., 911) or ask someone else to call. Time is critical.
If the person is conscious, help them sit down and rest in a comfortable position, ideally with their knees raised and head and shoulders supported.
Loosen any tight clothing around their neck and chest.
If the person is prescribed medication for chest pain, such as nitroglycerin, help them take it, as directed. Ensure they are not allergic and check the expiration date.
If the person becomes unresponsive and stops breathing, begin CPR if you are trained to do so. Follow the instructions of the emergency dispatcher.
Stay with the person and monitor their condition until emergency services arrive. Provide reassurance and keep them calm.
red_flags: Persistent chest pain that does not subside
guidelines.disclaimer: This information is for general first-aid guidance only and is not a substitute for professional medical care. If possible, seek help from a qualified medical professional or emergency services.

steps: Recognize the signs of a stroke (see red flags). Time is critical.
Note the time when symptoms first appeared. This information is important for medical professionals.
Immediately call emergency services (e.g., 911) or your local emergency number.
Keep the person calm and comfortable.
Loosen any tight clothing around the neck.
If the person is conscious, position them on their side with their head slightly elevated. This can help prevent choking if vomiting occurs.
Monitor their breathing and be prepared to administer CPR if necessary.
Do not give the person anything to eat or drink.
Stay with the person until emergency services arrive and provide them with the information you have.
red_flags: Sudden numbness or weakness of the face, arm, or leg, especially on one side of the body
Sudden confusion, trouble speaking, or difficulty understanding speech
Sudden trouble seeing in one or both eyes
Sudden severe headache with no known cause
Sudden trouble walking, dizziness, loss of balance, or coordination
Facial drooping (one side of the face droops when the person smiles)
guidelines.disclaimer: This information is for general first-aid guidance only and is not a substitute for professional medical care. If possible, seek help from a qualified medical professional or emergency services.

steps: If the person is conscious and able to swallow, give them something sweet to eat or drink, such as juice, glucose tablets, hard candy, or regular (non-diet) soda.
Follow the instructions on their glucose tablets or gel, or provide approximately 15 grams of fast-acting carbohydrates.
Wait 15 minutes and check their blood sugar again if possible. If it is still low, give another 15 grams of fast-acting carbohydrates.
Once their blood sugar is back to a normal level, or if they start to feel better, give them a longer-acting source of carbohydrates, such as crackers and cheese or a sandwich.
If the person is unconscious, having seizures, or unable to swallow, do NOT give them anything by mouth. Place them in the recovery position (on their side) to protect their airway.
Monitor their breathing and circulation.
red_flags: Blood sugar remains low after administering sugar
guidelines.disclaimer: This information is for general first-aid guidance only and is not a substitute for professional medical care. If possible, seek help from a qualified medical professional or emergency services.

steps: Help the person sit upright in a comfortable position. Do not have them lie down.
Assist them in using their inhaler. Shake the inhaler well and use a spacer if available.
Encourage them to take slow, deep breaths.
Loosen any tight clothing around their neck and chest.
Stay calm and reassure the person.
If symptoms do not improve after using the inhaler, or if they worsen, seek immediate medical attention.
red_flags: Inability to speak in full sentences
guidelines.disclaimer: This information is for general first-aid guidance only and is not a substitute for professional medical care. If possible, seek help from a qualified medical professional or emergency services.

steps: Recognize the signs of anaphylaxis: These can include hives, swelling (especially of the face, lips, or tongue), difficulty breathing or wheezing, throat tightness, dizziness, fainting, nausea, vomiting, or a rapid heartbeat.

If the person has an epinephrine auto-injector (EpiPen), help them use it promptly. Follow the instructions on the device. Inject into the outer mid-thigh, holding the injector in place for the prescribed time.
Call emergency services or seek immediate medical attention, even if symptoms improve after using epinephrine. Anaphylaxis can be life-threatening and may require further treatment.
If the person is having difficulty breathing, help them into a comfortable position, usually sitting upright.
Check the person's pulse and breathing. If they are not breathing, begin CPR if you are trained to do so.
If possible, try to identify the allergen that caused the reaction to avoid future exposure.
red_flags: Symptoms not improving after epinephrine injection
guidelines.disclaimer: This information is for general first-aid guidance only and is not a substitute for professional medical care. If possible, seek help from a qualified medical professional or emergency services.

steps: Check for responsiveness. If the person is unresponsive, call for emergency medical help immediately if available.
If the person is breathing, position them on their back and elevate their legs above their heart level to help restore blood flow to the brain.
Loosen any tight clothing, such as belts or collars.
Check for injuries caused by the fall.
Once the person regains consciousness, allow them to sit up slowly.
Offer the person water if they feel able to drink. Avoid giving them anything to eat or drink too quickly.
Keep the person under observation to ensure they recover fully.
red_flags: The person does not regain consciousness quickly.
The person has any injuries from the fall.
The person has a known heart condition or other serious medical condition.
The person is over 50 years old.
guidelines.disclaimer: This information is for general first-aid guidance only and is not a substitute for professional medical care. If possible, seek help from a qualified medical professional or emergency services.

steps: Stay hydrated by drinking clear fluids like water, broth, or electrolyte solutions in small sips.
Avoid solid foods until vomiting and diarrhea subside. Then, gradually introduce bland, easily digestible foods like crackers, toast, or bananas.
Get plenty of rest to allow your body to recover.
Avoid dairy products, caffeine, alcohol, and fatty or spicy foods, as these can worsen symptoms.
red_flags: Signs of dehydration (decreased urination, dizziness, extreme thirst)
Neurological symptoms (blurred vision, muscle weakness, tingling)
guidelines.disclaimer: This information is for general first-aid guidance only and is not a substitute for professional medical care. If possible, seek help from a qualified medical professional or emergency services.

steps: Immediately flush the affected area with large amounts of cool, running water for at least 20 minutes. If the chemical is in powder form, brush it off the skin before flushing with water.

Remove any contaminated clothing or jewelry carefully while flushing the area with water. If the chemical is in the eye, flush the eye with cool water, ensuring the water flows away from the unaffected eye.
If possible, determine the name of the chemical and provide this information to emergency services.
Cover the burn loosely with a sterile, non-adhesive dressing or clean cloth.
Monitor for signs of shock, such as rapid breathing, dizziness, or pale skin.
red_flags: Burns on the face, hands, feet, or genitals.
If the person is a young child or elderly.
If the person has other medical problems.
guidelines.disclaimer: This information is for general first-aid guidance only and is not a substitute for professional medical care. If possible, seek help from a qualified medical professional or emergency services.

steps: Immediately move the person to fresh air. Open windows and doors if safe to do so.
Call for emergency medical help (e.g., dial emergency services) as soon as possible.
If the person is not breathing, begin CPR if you are trained to do so.
Continue to monitor the person's condition until medical help arrives.
red_flags: Multiple people in the same location experiencing similar symptoms
guidelines.disclaimer: This information is for general first-aid guidance only and is not a substitute for professional medical care. If possible, seek help from a qualified medical professional or emergency services.

steps: If the person is conscious and able to swallow, try to identify the mushroom. If possible, save a sample of the mushroom for identification by medical professionals.

Contact your local poison control center or emergency services immediately. Provide them with as much information as possible, including the species of mushroom (if known), the amount ingested, and the person's symptoms.
Follow the instructions provided by the poison control center or emergency services.
If instructed, induce vomiting only if advised by a medical professional. Do not induce vomiting if the person is unconscious, having difficulty breathing, or experiencing seizures.
If vomiting occurs, collect a sample of the vomit for testing.
Monitor the person's vital signs (breathing, pulse) and be prepared to administer basic first aid such as CPR if necessary.
Keep the person comfortable and reassure them while waiting for medical assistance.
red_flags: Vomiting or diarrhea that won't stop
Yellowing of the skin or eyes (jaundice)
guidelines.disclaimer: This information is for general first-aid guidance only and is not a substitute for professional medical care. If possible, seek help from a qualified medical professional or emergency services.

steps: If the person is conscious, try to keep them awake and sitting up.
If the person is unconscious, immediately call for emergency medical help.
Check the person's breathing and pulse frequently. Be prepared to administer CPR if necessary.
If the person is breathing, turn them onto their side in the recovery position to prevent choking if they vomit.
Keep the person warm with a blanket.
Stay with the person and monitor their condition until medical help arrives.
Provide medical personnel with as much information as possible, including the amount and type of alcohol consumed.
red_flags: Slow or irregular breathing (fewer than 8 breaths per minute)
guidelines.disclaimer: This information is for general first-aid guidance only and is not a substitute for professional medical care. If possible, seek help from a qualified medical professional or emergency services.

steps: Move the person to a cooler place, such as shade or an air-conditioned area.
Remove any unnecessary clothing.
Cool the person quickly using any available methods, such as:
- Applying cool water to the skin (e.g., spraying with a hose, sponging with cool water).
- Applying ice packs to the groin, armpits, and neck.
- Fanning the person to increase cooling.
Monitor the person's temperature. Continue cooling efforts until the body temperature drops to a safer level (if a thermometer is available).
If the person is conscious and able to drink, give them cool water or a sports drink containing electrolytes.
If the person is experiencing seizures, protect them from injury and do not put anything in their mouth.
Stay with the person until medical help arrives.
red_flags: Hot, dry skin or profuse sweating
Confusion, altered mental state, or loss of consciousness
guidelines.disclaimer: This information is for general first-aid guidance only and is not a substitute for professional medical care. If possible, seek help from a qualified medical professional or emergency services.

steps: If you suspect altitude sickness, the most important step is to descend to a lower altitude as quickly and safely as possible. Even a small descent can help.
Stop ascending any further. Rest and avoid strenuous activity.
Drink plenty of fluids, but avoid alcohol and caffeine.
If you have a headache, you can take over-the-counter pain relievers like ibuprofen or acetaminophen, following the package instructions.
If symptoms are mild, give your body time to acclimatize at the lower altitude before resuming your ascent, and do so gradually.
red_flags: Severe headache that doesn't respond to pain relievers.
Shortness of breath, even at rest.
Confusion, disorientation, or changes in mental status.
Loss of coordination or difficulty walking.
Coughing, especially if producing frothy or pink sputum (possible sign of HAPE - High Altitude Pulmonary Edema).
guidelines.disclaimer: This information is for general first-aid guidance only and is not a substitute for professional medical care. If possible, seek help from a qualified medical professional or emergency services.

steps: Ensure the scene is safe. Lightning can strike more than once.
If the person is unresponsive, check for breathing and a pulse. If absent, begin CPR immediately.
Call for emergency medical help as quickly as possible.
Move the person to a safer location if necessary, but only if you are not putting yourself at risk.
Check for burns, especially at entry and exit points (e.g., where the lightning entered and exited the body).
Stabilize the person's head and neck in case of spinal injury.
Cover the person with a blanket to prevent shock and preserve body heat.
Provide reassurance and emotional support while waiting for medical help to arrive.
red_flags: Difficulty breathing or absence of breathing
Spinal injury (neck or back pain, numbness, or tingling)
guidelines.disclaimer: This information is for general first-aid guidance only and is not a substitute for professional medical care. If possible, seek help from a qualified medical professional or emergency services.

steps: Ensure your own safety first before attempting a rescue.
Remove the person from the water as quickly and safely as possible.
Check for responsiveness. If the person is unresponsive, immediately call for emergency medical services if available.
Check for breathing. If the person is not breathing or is gasping, begin rescue breathing or CPR, if you are trained.
If the person is breathing, place them in the recovery position (on their side) to help prevent aspiration of fluids.
Keep the person warm and monitor their breathing until medical help arrives.
guidelines.disclaimer: This information is for general first-aid guidance only and is not a substitute for professional medical care. If possible, seek help from a qualified medical professional or emergency services.

steps: If the person is conscious, encourage them to cough forcefully to try and clear their airway.
Monitor the person's breathing and level of consciousness closely.
If the person is unconscious or not breathing, begin CPR immediately. Follow standard CPR procedures, including chest compressions and rescue breaths.
If possible, administer oxygen if available and you are trained to do so.
Keep the person warm and calm while waiting for medical assistance.
red_flags: Difficulty breathing or shortness of breath
Bluish discoloration of the skin, lips, or nail beds (cyanosis)
guidelines.disclaimer: This information is for general first-aid guidance only and is not a substitute for professional medical care. If possible, seek help from a qualified medical professional or emergency services.

steps: Carefully remove the person from the water source.
Handle the person gently and avoid rough movements.
Remove any wet clothing immediately.
Dress the person in dry, warm clothing, including hat and gloves.
Cover the person with blankets or a warm sleeping bag to insulate them.
If available, offer warm, non-alcoholic, and non-caffeinated beverages to help raise their body temperature.
If the person is alert and able to swallow, provide high-energy foods like chocolate or energy bars.
Monitor the person's breathing and level of consciousness.
If the person is unconscious, check for breathing and pulse. Begin CPR if necessary.
red_flags: Uncontrollable shivering or shivering that stops suddenly
Loss of coordination or difficulty walking
Slow, shallow breathing or difficulty breathing
Very cold skin that does not improve with warming
guidelines.disclaimer: This information is for general first-aid guidance only and is not a substitute for professional medical care. If possible, seek help from a qualified medical professional or emergency services.

steps: If the stinger is visible, gently try to remove it. A credit card or similar object can be used to scrape it away. Avoid squeezing the stinger, which may release more venom.
Wash the area with soap and water.
Apply a cold compress or ice pack to the sting site for 10-20 minutes to help reduce swelling and pain.
Consider taking an over-the-counter pain reliever, such as ibuprofen or acetaminophen, to manage pain.
Monitor for signs of an allergic reaction.
red_flags: Swelling of the face, lips, tongue, or throat
Hives or rash over a large part of the body
Known severe allergy to bee stings (anaphylaxis)
guidelines.disclaimer: This information is for general first-aid guidance only and is not a substitute for professional medical care. If possible, seek help from a qualified medical professional or emergency services.

steps: Move the person to a cooler environment: shade, indoors, or air conditioning.
Remove excess clothing.
Cool the person quickly by any means available: cool water immersion, spraying with cool water, fanning, or applying ice packs to the groin, armpits, and neck.
Monitor body temperature and continue cooling efforts until the temperature drops to a safer level.
If the person is alert and able to drink, provide cool fluids (water or sports drinks).
Position the person on their side if they are showing signs of reduced consciousness to protect their airway.
red_flags: Confusion, disorientation, or altered mental status
Hot, dry skin or profuse sweating
guidelines.disclaimer: This information is for general first-aid guidance only and is not a substitute for professional medical care. If possible, seek help from a qualified medical professional or emergency services.

steps: If you suspect altitude sickness, the most important first step is to descend to a lower altitude as quickly and safely as possible.
Stop ascending any further. Your body needs time to adjust to the current altitude.
Rest and avoid strenuous activity. Physical exertion can worsen symptoms.
Stay hydrated by drinking plenty of fluids, but avoid alcohol and caffeine.
Consider taking over-the-counter pain relievers like ibuprofen or acetaminophen for headache relief. Follow package directions.
If symptoms are mild, give your body time to acclimatize at the lower altitude before attempting to ascend again, and do so gradually.
red_flags: Severe headache that doesn't respond to pain medication.
Shortness of breath, even at rest.
Coughing, especially if producing frothy or pink sputum.
Confusion, disorientation, or changes in mental state.
Difficulty walking or loss of coordination.
guidelines.disclaimer: This information is for general first-aid guidance only and is not a substitute for professional medical care. If possible, seek help from a qualified medical professional or emergency services.

steps: Ensure safety: Make sure the area is safe from further lightning strikes before approaching the person.
Check responsiveness: Gently tap the person and ask loudly if they are okay. If there is no response, call for emergency services immediately if available.
Assess breathing and circulation: Check for breathing and a pulse. If the person is not breathing or does not have a pulse, begin CPR immediately if you are trained to do so.
Treat burns: Lightning strikes can cause burns. Cool the burn with cool (not cold) water for several minutes. Cover the burn with a clean, dry dressing.
Look for other injuries: Check for fractures, dislocations, and other trauma. Stabilize any suspected fractures or dislocations.
Provide reassurance: If the person is conscious, reassure them and keep them calm while waiting for medical help to arrive.
red_flags: Difficulty breathing or absence of breathing
Any signs of trauma or injury
guidelines.disclaimer: This information is for general first-aid guidance only and is not a substitute for professional medical care. If possible, seek help from a qualified medical professional or emergency services.

steps: Ensure your own safety first before attempting a rescue.
Remove the person from the water if it is safe to do so.
Check for responsiveness. If the person is unresponsive, call for emergency medical help immediately.
Check for breathing. If the person is not breathing, begin rescue breathing. Give two initial breaths, then check for signs of life.
If there are no signs of life (breathing, coughing, or movement), begin chest compressions. Push hard and fast in the center of the chest.
Continue rescue breathing and chest compressions until emergency services arrive or the person shows signs of life.
If the person is breathing, place them in the recovery position (on their side) to help prevent aspiration.
Keep the person warm and monitor their breathing until medical help arrives.
guidelines.disclaimer: This information is for general first-aid guidance only and is not a substitute for professional medical care. If possible, seek help from a qualified medical professional or emergency services.

steps: If the person is conscious and coughing, encourage them to continue coughing to clear the airway.
Monitor the person's breathing and responsiveness.
If the person is having difficulty breathing, call for emergency medical help immediately.
If the person is unconscious and not breathing, begin CPR if you are trained to do so.
Keep the person warm and calm while waiting for medical assistance.
red_flags: Difficulty breathing or shortness of breath
Foam coming from the mouth or nose
guidelines.disclaimer: This information is for general first-aid guidance only and is not a substitute for professional medical care. If possible, seek help from a qualified medical professional or emergency services.

steps: Move the person to a warm, dry place immediately to prevent further heat loss.
Remove any wet clothing carefully. Replace with dry clothes, blankets, towels, or anything available to insulate them.
If possible, warm the person gradually. Use blankets, body heat, or a warm (not hot) compress to the neck, armpits, and groin.
Offer warm, non-alcoholic, and non-caffeinated drinks if the person is conscious and able to swallow.
Monitor the person's breathing and level of consciousness. Be prepared to administer CPR if necessary.
Keep the person still and handle them gently. Avoid massaging or rubbing their limbs, as this can cause further complications.
red_flags: Persistent shivering or shivering that stops suddenly
Loss of coordination or difficulty walking
Slow, shallow breathing or difficulty breathing
Very cold skin that is blue or pale
guidelines.disclaimer: This information is for general first-aid guidance only and is not a substitute for professional medical care. If possible, seek help from a qualified medical professional or emergency services.

steps: If the stinger is visible, gently scrape it away with a fingernail or a credit card edge. Avoid squeezing the stinger, as this may release more venom.
Wash the area with soap and water.
Apply a cold compress to the sting site to reduce swelling and pain.
Consider taking an over-the-counter antihistamine to help relieve itching and swelling. Follow the product instructions for dosage.
Monitor for signs of an allergic reaction.
red_flags: Swelling of the face, lips, tongue, or throat
Hives or rash spreading beyond the sting site
guidelines.disclaimer: This information is for general first-aid guidance only and is not a substitute for professional medical care. If possible, seek help from a qualified medical professional or emergency services.

steps: Call for emergency medical assistance immediately if possible.
Keep the person calm and still to slow the spread of venom.
Immobilize the bitten limb and keep it below heart level, if possible.
Remove any rings, watches, or restrictive clothing from the affected limb.
If possible and safe, note the snake's appearance (color, size, pattern) for identification, but do NOT try to catch or kill it.
Clean the wound gently with soap and water if available.
Cover the wound with a clean, dry dressing.
Monitor the person's breathing and circulation.
red_flags: Signs of allergic reaction (hives, itching, swelling of the face, tongue, or throat)
guidelines.disclaimer: This information is for general first-aid guidance only and is not a substitute for professional medical care. If possible, seek help from a qualified medical professional or emergency services.

steps: Wash the bite area gently with soap and water.
Apply a cold compress or ice pack to the bite for 10 minutes on and 10 minutes off to help reduce pain and swelling.
Elevate the affected area, if possible, to help minimize swelling.
Monitor for signs of infection or a severe reaction.
red_flags: A bite from a known dangerous spider (e.g., black widow, brown recluse)
guidelines.disclaimer: This information is for general first-aid guidance only and is not a substitute for professional medical care. If possible, seek help from a qualified medical professional or emergency services.

steps: Use fine-tipped tweezers to grasp the tick as close to the skin's surface as possible.
Pull the tick straight out with steady, even pressure. Do not twist or jerk the tick, as this can cause the mouthparts to break off and remain in the skin.
If the mouthparts break off and remain in the skin, try to remove them with tweezers. If you cannot remove them easily, leave them alone and let the skin heal.
After removing the tick, thoroughly clean the bite area and your hands with soap and water, rubbing alcohol, or an antiseptic.
Dispose of the tick by placing it in a sealed bag or container, wrapping it tightly in tape, or flushing it down the toilet.
Monitor the bite area for any signs of infection or rash.
red_flags: A rash, especially a bullseye-shaped rash
Signs of infection at the bite site (increased pain, redness, pus)
guidelines.disclaimer: This information is for general first-aid guidance only and is not a substitute for professional medical care. If possible, seek help from a qualified medical professional or emergency services.

steps: Move the person to a cooler environment, ideally an air-conditioned space or a shady area.
Remove any unnecessary clothing.
Cool the person quickly using any available methods such as: applying cool water to the skin, fanning the person, placing ice packs or cool, wet towels on the head, neck, armpits, and groin.
Monitor the person's temperature. Continue cooling efforts until the body temperature drops to a safer level (below 102°F or 39°C if possible).
If the person is alert and able to swallow, offer cool fluids like water or a sports drink. Avoid sugary drinks.
If the person shows signs of deteriorating condition, prepare to administer first aid for seizures or unconsciousness if needed.
red_flags: High body temperature (104°F or 40°C or higher)
Confusion, disorientation, or altered mental state
Hot, dry skin or profuse sweating
guidelines.disclaimer: This information is for general first-aid guidance only and is not a substitute for professional medical care. If possible, seek help from a qualified medical professional or emergency services.

steps: If you suspect altitude sickness, the most important step is to descend to a lower altitude as quickly and safely as possible. Even a small descent of 1,500 to 3,000 feet (450 to 900 meters) can help.
Stop ascending any further. Rest and avoid strenuous activity.
Stay hydrated by drinking plenty of fluids, but avoid alcohol and caffeine.
If you have mild symptoms like headache, you may take over-the-counter pain relievers.
Monitor symptoms closely for any worsening.
red_flags: Severe headache that doesn't respond to pain relievers.
Increasing shortness of breath, even at rest.
Cough with pink or frothy sputum (possible sign of HAPE - High Altitude Pulmonary Edema).
Confusion, disorientation, or changes in mental status (possible sign of HACE - High Altitude Cerebral Edema).
Difficulty walking or loss of coordination.
Blue or gray discoloration of the skin (cyanosis).
guidelines.disclaimer: This information is for general first-aid guidance only and is not a substitute for professional medical care. If possible, seek help from a qualified medical professional or emergency services.

steps: Ensure the scene is safe. Lightning can strike more than once.
If the person is unresponsive, check for breathing and a pulse. If absent, begin CPR immediately.
Call for emergency medical help as quickly as possible.
Move the person to a safer location if needed, but only if you can do so without endangering yourself.
Check for burns, especially entry and exit points (where the lightning entered and exited the body).
Provide first aid for burns by cooling them with water.
Look for other injuries, such as broken bones, and stabilize them if possible.
Keep the person warm and still while waiting for medical help to arrive.
red_flags: Difficulty breathing or absence of breathing
guidelines.disclaimer: This information is for general first-aid guidance only and is not a substitute for professional medical care. If possible, seek help from a qualified medical professional or emergency services.

steps: Immediately remove the person from the water, if safe to do so.
Call for emergency medical help or ask someone else to do so immediately.
Check for responsiveness. If the person is unresponsive and not breathing or only gasping, begin CPR. If you are not trained in CPR, follow the dispatcher's instructions.
If the person is responsive, monitor their breathing and level of consciousness.
Keep the person warm and dry.
Even if the person seems to recover fully, they need to be evaluated by a medical professional due to the risk of delayed complications like pulmonary edema.
red_flags: Difficulty breathing or shortness of breath
Froth or foam coming from the mouth or nose
guidelines.disclaimer: This information is for general first-aid guidance only and is not a substitute for professional medical care. If possible, seek help from a qualified medical professional or emergency services.

steps: If the person is responsive and coughing, encourage them to continue coughing to clear their airway.
If the person is unresponsive, check for breathing. If they are not breathing, begin CPR.
If the person is breathing, place them in the recovery position (on their side) to help prevent further aspiration of fluids.
Keep the person warm and calm while waiting for medical assistance.
Monitor the person's breathing and level of consciousness closely.
red_flags: Difficulty breathing or shortness of breath
Decreased level of consciousness or unresponsiveness
guidelines.disclaimer: This information is for general first-aid guidance only and is not a substitute for professional medical care. If possible, seek help from a qualified medical professional or emergency services.

steps: Gently remove the person from the water or cold environment.
Handle the person gently. Hypothermia can make the heart sensitive, so avoid rough movements.
Remove any wet clothing carefully and replace with dry, warm clothing. Cover the head, neck, and groin area.
If dry clothing isn't available, use a blanket, towels, coats, or whatever is on hand to provide insulation.
Offer warm, non-caffeinated, non-alcoholic beverages if the person is alert and able to swallow.
Apply warm compresses to the center of the body—neck, chest, and groin.
Monitor the person's breathing and level of consciousness. Be prepared to administer CPR if necessary.
Continue to keep the person warm and monitor them until medical help arrives.
guidelines.disclaimer: This information is for general first-aid guidance only and is not a substitute for professional medical care. If possible, seek help from a qualified medical professional or emergency services.

steps: If the stinger is visible, gently try to remove it. A credit card or other rigid edge can be used to scrape it out. Avoid squeezing the venom sac.
Wash the area with soap and water.
Apply a cold compress to the sting site to reduce swelling and pain.
Consider using over-the-counter antihistamines or topical creams to relieve itching and swelling, following package directions.
red_flags: Swelling of the face, lips, or tongue
Hives or rash spreading beyond the sting site
guidelines.disclaimer: This information is for general first-aid guidance only and is not a substitute for professional medical care. If possible, seek help from a qualified medical professional or emergency services.

steps: Call for emergency medical help immediately (e.g., dial emergency services).
Keep the person calm and still to slow the spread of venom.
Immobilize the bitten limb. Use a splint or sling to keep it still.
Remove any rings, bracelets, or tight clothing from the bitten limb.
If possible, note the time of the bite and the snake's appearance (color and pattern) to help with identification, but do not risk further bites.
Keep the bite below the level of the heart, if possible.
Clean the wound with soap and water if available.
red_flags: Swelling around the bite area that continues to worsen
Signs of allergic reaction (hives, swelling of the face or tongue)
guidelines.disclaimer: This information is for general first-aid guidance only and is not a substitute for professional medical care. If possible, seek help from a qualified medical professional or emergency services.

steps: Wash the bite area gently with soap and water.
Apply a cold compress or ice pack to the bite for 10-15 minutes at a time to help reduce swelling and pain.
Elevate the affected area, if possible, to help minimize swelling.
Monitor for signs of infection or a severe reaction.
red_flags: A rapidly growing ulcer at the bite site
guidelines.disclaimer: This information is for general first-aid guidance only and is not a substitute for professional medical care. If possible, seek help from a qualified medical professional or emergency services.

steps: Use fine-tipped tweezers to grasp the tick as close to the skin's surface as possible.
Pull the tick straight out with steady, even pressure. Do not twist or jerk the tick, as this can cause the mouthparts to break off and remain in the skin.
If the mouthparts break off and remain in the skin, try to remove them with tweezers. If you are unable to remove them easily, leave them alone and let the skin heal.
After removing the tick, thoroughly clean the bite area and your hands with soap and water, rubbing alcohol, or an iodine scrub.
Monitor the bite area for any signs of infection, such as redness, swelling, or pus.
red_flags: Development of a rash, especially a bullseye-shaped rash.
Fever, chills, fatigue, headache, or muscle aches.
Neurological symptoms, such as numbness, tingling, or weakness.
guidelines.disclaimer: This information is for general first-aid guidance only and is not a substitute for professional medical care. If possible, seek help from a qualified medical professional or emergency services.

steps: Rinse the area with vinegar for at least 30 seconds. If vinegar is not available, use seawater.
Carefully remove any visible tentacles with a gloved hand, tweezers, or a stick. Avoid direct skin contact.
Apply a cold pack or ice pack wrapped in a cloth to the affected area for pain relief. Do not apply ice directly to the skin.
If itching persists, consider applying hydrocortisone cream to the affected area.
Monitor for signs of an allergic reaction or worsening symptoms.
red_flags: Swelling of the face, lips, or tongue
guidelines.disclaimer: This information is for general first-aid guidance only and is not a substitute for professional medical care. If possible, seek help from a qualified medical professional or emergency services.

steps: Wash the wound thoroughly with soap and water. Rinse well.
Slow any bleeding with a clean cloth. Apply firm pressure.
Apply an antibiotic ointment to the wound.
Cover the wound with a sterile bandage.
Monitor for signs of infection (redness, swelling, pus, increased pain).
If the skin is broken, seek medical attention to evaluate the need for a tetanus booster and rabies prevention.
red_flags: Signs of infection (redness, swelling, pus, increased pain)
Bite from an animal that appears sick or is behaving strangely
You are unsure of the animal's vaccination status
You have not had a tetanus shot in the last 5 years
guidelines.disclaimer: This information is for general first-aid guidance only and is not a substitute for professional medical care. If possible, seek help from a qualified medical professional or emergency services.

steps: Wash your hands thoroughly with soap and water.
If the bite broke the skin, wash the wound immediately with soap and water for several minutes.
Apply direct pressure with a clean cloth to stop any bleeding.
Apply an antiseptic ointment to the wound.
Cover the wound with a sterile bandage.
Change the bandage daily and keep the wound clean and dry.
Seek medical attention as soon as possible, as human bites have a high risk of infection.
red_flags: Signs of infection (increased pain, redness, swelling, pus or discharge, fever)
You are unable to stop the bleeding
Bite is on the face, hand, or near a joint
You have not had a tetanus shot in the last 5 years
The bite was from someone unknown or potentially carrying a disease
guidelines.disclaimer: This information is for general first-aid guidance only and is not a substitute for professional medical care. If possible, seek help from a qualified medical professional or emergency services.

steps: Wash the bite area gently with soap and water.
Apply a cold compress or ice pack to the bite for 10-20 minutes to help reduce swelling and itching.
Avoid scratching the bite, as this can increase the risk of infection.
If itching is bothersome, consider using an over-the-counter anti-itch cream or antihistamine.
red_flags: Bleeding from the gums or nose
Signs of infection at the bite site (increased pain, redness, swelling, pus)
guidelines.disclaimer: This information is for general first-aid guidance only and is not a substitute for professional medical care. If possible, seek help from a qualified medical professional or emergency services.

steps: Wash the sting area gently with soap and water.
Apply a cool compress or ice pack to the site for 10-20 minutes at a time to help reduce pain and swelling.
Elevate the affected area, if possible, to help minimize swelling.
Over-the-counter pain relievers like ibuprofen or acetaminophen may help manage pain (follow package instructions for appropriate dosage).
Keep the person calm and monitor for any signs of a severe reaction.
red_flags: Severe pain at the sting site
Hives or rash spreading away from the sting
Swelling of the face, lips, or tongue
guidelines.disclaimer: This information is for general first-aid guidance only and is not a substitute for professional medical care. If possible, seek help from a qualified medical professional or emergency services.

steps: Carefully brush off the ants; do not crush them, as this will release more venom and cause more stings.
Wash the area thoroughly with soap and water.
Apply a cold compress to the sting site to help reduce swelling and pain. Apply for 10-15 minutes at a time.
If itching is severe, consider using an over-the-counter antihistamine or applying a topical anti-itch cream (follow product instructions).
Avoid scratching the stings to prevent infection.
red_flags: Swelling of the tongue, throat, or face
Hives or rash spreading beyond the sting area
guidelines.disclaimer: This information is for general first-aid guidance only and is not a substitute for professional medical care. If possible, seek help from a qualified medical professional or emergency services.

steps: Immerse the affected area in hot (but not scalding) water for 30-90 minutes. Check the water temperature frequently to avoid burns.
Carefully remove any visible spines with tweezers. Be gentle to avoid breaking the spines further.
Wash the area thoroughly with soap and water.
Monitor for signs of infection (increased pain, redness, swelling, pus).
If a spine is deeply embedded or near a joint, do not attempt to remove it yourself.
red_flags: Signs of allergic reaction (hives, difficulty breathing, swelling of the face or throat)
Spine embedded deeply or near a joint
Signs of infection (increased pain, redness, swelling, pus)
Bleeding that doesn't stop with direct pressure
guidelines.disclaimer: This information is for general first-aid guidance only and is not a substitute for professional medical care. If possible, seek help from a qualified medical professional or emergency services.

steps: If possible, call for professional medical help or emergency services immediately.
Keep the injured person still and calm.
Examine the injured area for open wounds; if present, control bleeding before splinting.
Immobilize the injured limb or area using a splint and padding to minimize movement. If you don't have a splint, use a rigid object and secure it with tape or cloth.
Apply ice packs to the injured area to help reduce swelling and pain.
Monitor the person for any signs of shock (e.g., pale skin, rapid breathing).
red_flags: Visible bone protruding through the skin.
Loss of pulse or sensation in the injured limb.
Signs of shock (e.g., rapid heartbeat, shallow breathing, confusion).
Inability to move the injured limb.
guidelines.disclaimer: This information is for general first-aid guidance only and is not a substitute for professional medical care. If possible, seek help from a qualified medical professional or emergency services.

steps: Rest: Avoid putting weight on the ankle as much as possible.
Ice: Apply an ice pack to the injured area for 15-20 minutes every 2-3 hours. Wrap the ice pack in a cloth to protect the skin.
Compression: Use an elastic bandage to wrap the ankle, but not too tightly. The wrapping should provide support but not cut off circulation.
Elevation: Keep the ankle elevated above the heart to help reduce swelling.
Pain Relief: Over-the-counter pain relievers like ibuprofen or acetaminophen may help manage pain.
red_flags: Inability to put any weight on the ankle.
Numbness or tingling in the foot.
Signs of infection, such as fever, redness, or pus.
guidelines.disclaimer: This information is for general first-aid guidance only and is not a substitute for professional medical care. If possible, seek help from a qualified medical professional or emergency services.

steps: If there is bleeding, apply firm pressure to the wound with a clean cloth.
If the person is unconscious, check for breathing and pulse. If absent, begin CPR if you are trained.
Keep the person still and support their head and neck to prevent movement.
If the person is conscious, keep them calm and monitor their condition.
Apply a cold compress to the injured area to help reduce swelling.
red_flags: Clear fluid draining from the nose or ears
Weakness or numbness in arms or legs
guidelines.disclaimer: This information is for general first-aid guidance only and is not a substitute for professional medical care. If possible, seek help from a qualified medical professional or emergency services.

steps: Handle the tooth carefully. Avoid touching the root.
Rinse the tooth gently with clean water if it's dirty. Do not scrub it.
If possible, try to re-implant the tooth in its socket. Gently push it in using your fingers or by biting down on a soft cloth. Make sure the tooth is facing the correct way.
If you can't re-implant the tooth, store it in milk, saline solution, or saliva.
Seek immediate dental attention. The sooner you see a dentist, the better the chance of saving the tooth.
red_flags: Severe pain that does not subside.
Other injuries to the mouth or face.
guidelines.disclaimer: This information is for general first-aid guidance only and is not a substitute for professional medical care. If possible, seek help from a qualified medical professional or emergency services.

steps: For minor irritation with no vision loss: Gently flush the eye with clean, lukewarm water for 15-20 minutes.
If a foreign object is visible and easily removable: Gently try to remove it with a clean, damp cloth or cotton swab. Do not rub the eye.
If a chemical is in the eye: Immediately flush the eye continuously with clean water for at least 20 minutes, holding the eyelid open.
For a cut or puncture: Do not apply pressure. Gently cover the eye with a clean, protective shield (like a cup) and seek immediate medical attention.
In all cases, avoid rubbing or touching the injured eye.
red_flags: Vision loss or changes in vision
Foreign object embedded in the eye
Cut or puncture to the eye or eyelid
guidelines.disclaimer: This information is for general first-aid guidance only and is not a substitute for professional medical care. If possible, seek help from a qualified medical professional or emergency services.

steps: Wash your hands thoroughly with soap and water to help prevent infection.
Gently clean the wound with mild soap and water. Avoid scrubbing.
If the wound is bleeding, apply direct pressure with a clean cloth to stop the bleeding.
Once the bleeding has stopped, apply a thin layer of antibiotic ointment to help prevent infection.
Cover the wound with a sterile bandage.
Change the bandage daily or more often if it becomes dirty or wet.
Watch for signs of infection, such as increased pain, redness, swelling, pus, or fever.
red_flags: Deep wound or significant bleeding that doesn't stop with direct pressure.
Puncture wound to the head, chest, abdomen, or any area with major blood vessels.
Wound contaminated with dirt, gravel, or other debris that cannot be easily removed.
Signs of infection, such as increased pain, redness, swelling, pus, or fever.
If the puncture was caused by a rusty object or an animal bite, or if you are not up-to-date on your tetanus vaccination.
guidelines.disclaimer: This information is for general first-aid guidance only and is not a substitute for professional medical care. If possible, seek help from a qualified medical professional or emergency services.

steps: Apply the tourniquet 2-3 inches above the wound on the injured limb.
If possible, apply the tourniquet over bare skin to avoid trapping clothing in the device.
Tighten the tourniquet until the bright red bleeding stops. It needs to be tight enough to fully stop the flow of blood.
Secure the tourniquet according to the manufacturer's instructions.
Note the time of application on the tourniquet or nearby. This information is crucial for medical personnel.
If bleeding continues, a second tourniquet may be applied just above the first.
red_flags: Signs of shock (e.g., altered mental status, rapid heart rate, pale skin).
Numbness, tingling, or loss of sensation in the limb *below* the tourniquet.
guidelines.disclaimer: This information is for general first-aid guidance only and is not a substitute for professional medical care. If possible, seek help from a qualified medical professional or emergency services.

steps: Recognize the signs of shock: pale, cool, clammy skin; rapid, weak pulse; rapid breathing; nausea or vomiting; weakness; dizziness or lightheadedness; altered mental state (confusion or anxiety); dilated pupils.
If the person is conscious, lay them on their back and elevate their legs about 12 inches unless you suspect a spinal injury. If a spinal injury is suspected, keep the person still.
Loosen any tight clothing.
Keep the person warm and comfortable. Cover them with a blanket if possible.

If the person is conscious and able to swallow, you can offer small sips of clear fluids. Avoid giving anything to eat or drink if they are nauseous, vomiting, or have a decreased level of consciousness.
Monitor the person's breathing and pulse. Be prepared to administer CPR if necessary.
red_flags: Difficulty breathing or shortness of breath
Signs of a stroke (e.g., facial drooping, slurred speech, weakness on one side of the body)
guidelines.disclaimer: This information is for general first-aid guidance only and is not a substitute for professional medical care. If possible, seek help from a qualified medical professional or emergency services.

steps: If safe, help the person into a comfortable position, generally sitting or semi-sitting, to aid breathing.
Loosen any tight clothing around the chest and neck.
Encourage deep, slow breaths if possible, but do not force if painful.
Control any external bleeding by applying pressure to the wound. Seal open chest wounds immediately with an airtight material, such as plastic wrap, taped on three sides.
If the person becomes unresponsive, prepare to administer CPR.
Reassure the person and monitor their condition closely while waiting for medical help.
red_flags: Severe difficulty breathing or shortness of breath
Signs of shock (e.g., rapid heart rate, pale skin, confusion)
guidelines.disclaimer: This information is for general first-aid guidance only and is not a substitute for professional medical care. If possible, seek help from a qualified medical professional or emergency services.

steps: 1. Call for emergency medical help immediately if available.
2. If the person is conscious, help them lie on their back with their knees bent. This position can help to relax the abdominal muscles.
3. Keep the person still and calm. Movement can worsen internal injuries.
4. If there is an open wound, cover it with a sterile dressing, if available. If not, use a clean cloth.
5. Apply gentle pressure to the wound to help control bleeding, but avoid pushing on any protruding organs or objects.
6. Keep the person warm with a blanket or coat.
7. Monitor the person's breathing and pulse. Be prepared to perform CPR if necessary.
red_flags: Signs of shock (e.g., rapid pulse, shallow breathing, pale skin, confusion)
Blood in vomit, urine, or stool
Penetrating injury (e.g., gunshot wound, stab wound)
guidelines.disclaimer: This information is for general first-aid guidance only and is not a substitute for professional medical care. If possible, seek help from a qualified medical professional or emergency services.

steps: Call for emergency medical help immediately. Do not attempt to move the person unless absolutely necessary to protect them from immediate danger (e.g., fire).
Keep the person still.  Instruct them not to move their head or neck.
Manually stabilize the head and neck by holding the head in a neutral, in-line position, preventing any twisting or bending.  Maintain this support until emergency services arrive.
If trained, use a cervical collar to help stabilize the neck, but only if you are confident in its proper application.  Improper use can worsen the injury.
If possible, check for sensation and movement in the extremities (arms, legs) without moving the person significantly. Note any loss of function or feeling.
Reassure the person and keep them calm while waiting for professional help.
red_flags: Numbness, tingling, or weakness in arms or legs
Loss of bowel or bladder control
Obvious deformity of the neck or back
guidelines.disclaimer: This information is for general first-aid guidance only and is not a substitute for professional medical care. If possible, seek help from a qualified medical professional or emergency services.

steps: Help the person find a comfortable position. Sitting upright may be easier for breathing.
Encourage slow, deep breaths. This can help prevent shallow breathing, which can lead to pneumonia.
Offer pain relief. Over-the-counter pain relievers like ibuprofen or acetaminophen may help, but follow dosage instructions carefully.
Support the injured area. A pillow or blanket held against the chest can provide support when coughing or moving.
Avoid tight binding of the chest. This can restrict breathing.
red_flags: Severe difficulty breathing or shortness of breath
Severe pain that does not improve with pain relievers
Signs of shock (e.g., rapid heartbeat, dizziness, confusion)
guidelines.disclaimer: This information is for general first-aid guidance only and is not a substitute for professional medical care. If possible, seek help from a qualified medical professional or emergency services.

steps: 1. Wash your hands thoroughly with soap and water to prevent infection.
2. If possible, put on gloves before providing first aid.
3. Rinse the cut with clean, running water to remove dirt and debris.
4. Wash around the cut with soap and water, avoiding getting soap directly in the wound.

5. Stop the bleeding by applying direct pressure to the wound with a clean cloth. Maintain pressure until bleeding stops. If the bleeding is severe, apply continuous pressure and seek immediate medical attention.
6. Once the bleeding has stopped, apply a thin layer of antibiotic ointment to protect against infection.
7. Cover the cut with a sterile bandage. Change the bandage daily, or more often if it becomes wet or dirty.
8. Watch for signs of infection, such as increased pain, redness, swelling, pus, or fever.
red_flags: Deep wound exposing muscle or bone
Signs of infection (increased pain, redness, swelling, pus, fever)
Cut from a dirty or rusty object (risk of tetanus)
guidelines.disclaimer: This information is for general first-aid guidance only and is not a substitute for professional medical care. If possible, seek help from a qualified medical professional or emergency services.

steps: If the blister is small and not painful, leave it intact. This helps protect the skin underneath and prevents infection.
If the blister is large, painful, or likely to burst on its own, you may carefully drain it:
Wash your hands thoroughly with soap and water.
Sterilize a needle by wiping it with rubbing alcohol.
Gently puncture the edge of the blister in several places.
Allow the fluid to drain completely, but leave the blister roof intact.
Clean the drained blister with soap and water. Do not remove the skin unless it is very dirty or infected.
Apply a thin layer of antibiotic ointment (if available) and cover the blister with a clean, dry bandage.
Change the bandage daily or more often if it becomes wet or dirty.
Avoid wearing shoes or clothing that caused the blister until it has healed.
red_flags: Signs of infection, such as increased pain, redness, swelling, pus, or fever.
Blisters that keep recurring in the same location.
Blisters that appear for no apparent reason or are associated with a medical condition.
Blisters caused by a burn or allergic reaction.
guidelines.disclaimer: This information is for general first-aid guidance only and is not a substitute for professional medical care. If possible, seek help from a qualified medical professional or emergency services.

steps: Wash your hands thoroughly with soap and water to prevent infection.
Clean the area around the foreign object with soap and water.
If the object is small and close to the surface (like a splinter), try to remove it with sterilized tweezers. Sterilize the tweezers by cleaning them with rubbing alcohol.
Gently grasp the exposed end of the object with the tweezers and pull it out at the same angle it entered the skin.
If the object is deeply embedded, large, or near a vital area (e.g., eye), do NOT attempt to remove it. Stabilize the object as best you can.
After removing the object, wash the area again with soap and water.
Apply a clean bandage to protect the area.
Monitor for signs of infection (redness, swelling, pus, increased pain).
red_flags: Object is deeply embedded or large.
Object is near a vital area (eye, major blood vessel).
You cannot remove the object easily.
Signs of infection develop (redness, swelling, pus, increased pain, fever).
The person has not had a tetanus shot in the last 5 years, especially with a dirty or rusty object.
guidelines.disclaimer: This information is for general first-aid guidance only and is not a substitute for professional medical care. If possible, seek help from a qualified medical professional or emergency services.

steps: Immediately cool the burn under cool (not cold) running water for 10-20 minutes. If running water isn't available, apply a cool compress.
After cooling, gently clean the burn with mild soap and water.
Apply a thin layer of antibiotic ointment or burn cream to the burn.
Cover the burn loosely with a sterile, non-stick bandage. Change the bandage daily.
Over-the-counter pain relievers like ibuprofen or acetaminophen can help manage pain.
red_flags: The burn covers a large area of the body (larger than the palm of your hand).
The burn is on the face, hands, feet, genitals, or major joints.
The burn is deep, involving all layers of the skin or underlying tissues.
The burned area shows signs of infection, such as increased pain, redness, swelling, pus, or fever.
guidelines.disclaimer: This information is for general first-aid guidance only and is not a substitute for professional medical care. If possible, seek help from a qualified medical professional or emergency services.

steps: Ensure your own safety and the safety of the person by removing them from the source of the burn if it is safe to do so.
Call for emergency medical help immediately. Severe burns require professional medical attention.
While waiting for help to arrive, check the person's breathing and circulation. If necessary, begin CPR.
Do not remove any clothing that is stuck to the burn.
Cool the burn with large amounts of cool or cold (not ice) water for at least 10 minutes or until emergency services arrive. If clean water is not available, use any cool, non-toxic liquid.
Cover the burn loosely with a sterile, non-adhesive bandage or clean cloth. Do not apply creams, lotions, or ointments.
Keep the person warm and comfortable to prevent shock.
red_flags: Burns covering a large area of the body
Burns on the face, hands, feet, genitals, or major joints
Burns that encircle an arm or leg
Signs of shock (e.g., pale skin, rapid heartbeat, altered mental state)
Burns caused by chemicals or electricity
Burns in young children or elderly individuals
guidelines.disclaimer: This information is for general first-aid guidance only and is not a substitute for professional medical care. If possible, seek help from a qualified medical professional or emergency services.

steps: Ensure the scene is safe: Disconnect the power source if possible, but only if it is safe to do so. Otherwise, call emergency services.
Do not approach the person if they are still in contact with the electrical source.
Check for breathing and a pulse. If absent, begin CPR if you are trained to do so.
Once the person is safely away from the electrical source, assess the burn. Look for entry and exit wounds.
Cool the burn with cool (not cold) running water for 10-20 minutes.
Cover the burn with a sterile, non-adhesive bandage or clean cloth.
Monitor the person for signs of shock, such as pale skin, rapid breathing, and altered mental status.
